@elena, no, you are missing the point, as so many Europeans do. Americans are criticized for not understanding every culture on Earth, yet few Europeans bother to understand our culture before commenting.

See also my response to S.E.H., particularly to American ideas on fairness and politics. Bottom line, the OP's comment is not driven by ideology, we do not conflate sports and politics, full stop.

While the "old woman" comment is not particularly articulate, the point remains that we do not like athletes who act like they have been hit with a club when they have been slightly brushed by an opponent (or, in many cases, not touched at all!) That is not the sporting culture we grow up with and have ingrained into us as kids.

Note that American football is imported (it grew out of rugby, from England), hockey is from Canada (I believe, by way of Holland), golf is Scottish, tennis, France/England ... even baseball is really English. Association football is growing in popularity by leaps and bounds as well, so you cannot say if a sport is not an American invention, we find it worthless. But, the diving, whining and other dirty play - yes, we find that not only worthless, but disgusting.

Maybe, Josh. It's difficult to know how 'out of its way' the article goes; i.e., whether this awkward (or more accurately, absurd) question was exceptional or typical. I tend to think, given that the chair of the panel chose not to show the trauma report to the two other panelists; that they wrapped-up the investigation so quickly (not to mention, tidily); that a bookstore employee served on the panel; that the transcript examples cited in the article reflect such a confused, non-linear line of questioning; that Anna's answers were interrupted; that she was not provided some of the information (resulting from the panel's inquiries) prior to being questioned about them; that some of that information was inaccurately quoted: all of this combines to suggest a reprehensible level of incompetence and a horribly botched process. Because of what was (potentially) at stake -- violent criminal and traumatizing behavior -- these mistakes do add up to something malign.

his whole article is about "making it look as if they [the university] represent something malign."  I believe the school followed every protocol and training and interrogation processes with concern for both victim and accused.  we're not privy to all facts and disclosures so it's best not to judge on this author's unique viewpoint (he is very close friends of this girl's family).

If Ms. Sandra Bissell is proud of the review panel's work here, it frightens me to think what she might be ashamed of. “A great deal of care and focus goes into this work, including extensive training in advance of our service, as well as refresher training prior to serving on a particular panel,” she said.

And 2-8% is a generous number, considering that many police have been found to file rape cases they chose not to pursue as "false accusations." A recent study found the number to be less than 1% (Levitt et al 2013)

I think you guys are all drinking the same kool-aid; using the same flawed analysis of the statistics.

The report linked by nadia attempts to prove that a vast majority of rape cases are not properly handled by police departments, provided as evidence that going to the police is not an option for this victim.

This report uses FBI numbers (which it later discredits) as a baseline for what rape numbers should be. You cannot assume something is true, then later discredit it in your analysis, that is typically called circular logic (or a proof by contradiction if you are trying to prove the initial assumption false).

This same logic pattern is present in your post. You cannot say that 2-8% are false and say that only 7% go to jail with any high level of certainty. How is the condition for establishing false claims attained? I would assume that it isn't through jury convictions, otherwise your 7% incarceration rate would imply judges are overriding jury convictions, instead through data extrapolation, making the claim suspect at best. This same extrapolated data is likely fueling the claim that only 3% (not 7%) go to prison as it is in nadia's reference. Furthermore, your case is complicated by the fact that large numbers are not reported, making sound extrapolation from a small sample size difficult. Essentially your proof is non-mathematicians trying to do math and doing it badly.

Is there a problem with reporting? Yes. But lets not do bad math to prove it.

I served on these academic hearing boards throughout undergraduate and graduate school as a service to the school community.

I'm surprised that Hobart and William smith college decided to take on a case where a student had been assaulted by another student. In all the schools whose boards I've served on, these cases are usually not handled or investigated internally. If a criminal court finds a student guilty, they would most certainly be expelled from campus by the academic board. In this case, Anna should have filed a police report and pressed charges immediately.

Also, in all the boards I've served in, there are usually two faculty members, a staff member, and a member of the student body. Students need to believe that the board is impartial, which is why it's important to have a student on the panel.

Or you can put the needs of your child ahead of "the parents' own selfish need" to do other things in the evening. It works both ways. And it also seems quite condescending to suggest that "underprivileged families" are the ones who "can't" get their children to bed at an early hour. There are plenty of UMC families who don't have a set bedtime. When my own children were in preschool, several of their classmates were wined and dined late into the evening because their parents wanted to go out after work. These were not poor, underprivileged families struggling to get by, these were parents who didn't want to change lifestyle just because they had kids.
You may argue with whether children should go to bed early or not, but please don't make this about "poor" vs "rich".

You say you haven't been modeling this behavior and I velieve you. But have you been modeling the behavior you want them to engage in? "Wow. The drive was a pain but this place is beautiful. I feel lucky to be here"

Moreover, there is a difference between not complaining and actually being grateful. And to be fair maybe for the 9 year old the drive really isn't worth it. You can tell him to keep his complaints to himself. But it's a lot to ask anyone to be greatful for things they may not actually want that much.
My experience is the more parents push the kid to feel greatful or act vindictively if they are not the less likely kids are going to really get to a place where they feel it genuinely.

And finally yes. Some of this is temperamental. Some people naturally feel and are able to express gratitude more easily.

I call my kids (and students) out on that type of behavior, and rather pedantically go over the script for a better conversation with respect to gratitude. Sometimes expectations have to be taught directly. And I also limit choices in terms of what kids can have a say in. Not a big enough piece of chocolate? Fine, give it to me, no one needs chocolate, anyway. The things that are gifts and treats are optional: if they aren't pleased with it, then you can take it back (Kid: "Oh wait! I changed my mind. Thank you.")

All that said, one of the best models for progressive involvement in independence and decision making is "girl planning" in the Girl Scouts: that is, give the kids more and more choice, autonomy and responsibility as they get older.

i wonder if letting them have a say in things would help. instead of 5-hour drive with a pool at the end being presented as a fait accompli, maybe consider asking their top vacation priorities first and try to work in at least one, or come up with two possibilities and ask for input.
as for the gratitude on a chocolate level, for us it seems to be a matter of constantly requiring them to say the right words, in the hope that a) the feelings will follow and b) even if they don't, the right words ("Please can I have," not "I want"; "Thank you," not "okay") will become enough of a habit that it won't matter all that much.

Here's a rant.

Sometimes I can't believe how ungrateful kids can be.

We just booked a great place in the mountains, with a pool(that, for them, of course), and our nine year old says, at the news, 'I don't want to drive 5 hours to get there. It's boring.'

If we go out for dinner, they complain about where. Our 5 year old, when offered a piece of chocolate, invariably complains 'I want a bigger piece', instead of simply thank you.

My DH and I are both pretty positive people, so I don't think we've been modelling this behavior.

Are people born negative, or can we do something about it? Are all kids this way? Will they grow out of it?

They appreciate that many children aren't as fortunate as them, and I encourage them to see what they HAVE instead of what isn't there, but for now the grass is always greener on the other side of the fence.

It makes me want to stop trying to please them with anything.

@Susan,

We have American friends who have lived overseas for years (first South Africa, now Saudi Arabia) who sent their kids to camp in Massachusetts for four weeks every summer starting at the age of 7. The mom came along and worked at the camp. Then they all visited family in the US before returning home.

Nobody's suggesting that the kid travel alone.

comments.commentBody: I am sorry the rigidity frustrates you, but I would submit that the other stuff like seeing the parents or having a hot family dinner takes a back seat to enough sleep. I have put my money where my mouth is - I used to work full time and often wasn't home when it was time for the kids to go to bed and family dinners were a pipe dream. My priority was making sure they had enough sleep. They could catch up on quality time with me on weekends - the sleep, once lost, was gone forever.

I remember having read that article. The school started this as an experiment since the children were sleeping hardly at home due to all kinds of tensions.

This school started to work as per the experiment and also by making sleeping arrangements for the students in school itself. I am not sure how successful this school is since the photograph published in the article had clearly shown a girl checking her phone instead of sleeping. This is one of cancer like problems with the kids.

The teenagers waste most of the time in cell phone talk,messaging,computer chat,Facebook etc and then they blame excessive homework and project work for their tensions. If parents have proper control over the kids,things can always be managed better.

We were teenagers once and we sincerely followed the old saying for good. Thank God,we didn't have Phones,TV,Calculator,Video games and computers,still we were better off by miles.
So are you saying that the solution to children being left in cars on accident is that parents shouldn't work?

I am definitely attempting to teach my children between 'want to' and 'have to.' The fact that I could do this during grocery shopping is a an added bonus. I like the fact that the kids saw the cost of the wasted apples. That's very practical and real.
